articles.title: Automate repository tasks with GitHub Agentic Workflows
articles.description: Discover GitHub Agentic Workflows, now in technical preview. Build automations using coding agents in GitHub Actions to handle triage, documentation, code quality, and more. The post Automate repository tasks with GitHub Agentic Workflows appeared first on The GitHub Blog .
articles.content: Imagine visiting your repository in the morning and feeling calm because you see: Issues triaged and labelled CI failures investigated with proposed fixes Documentation has been updated to reflect recent code changes. Two new pull requests that improve testing await your review. All of it visible, inspectable, and operating within the boundaries you’ve defined. That’s the future powered by GitHub Agentic Workflows : automated, intent-driven repository workflows that run in GitHub Act
articles.author: Don Syme

articles.description: In a world where AI is replacing human workers, using up energy and water, and deepening disconnect, is AI for humanitarian good even possible? The answer is yes. In the first part of this two part series, we're taking a look at just a few AI do-gooders and what they're doing to fight clim
articles.content: In a world where AI is replacing human workers, using up energy and water, and deepening disconnect, is AI for humanitarian good even possible? The answer is yes. In the first part of this two part series, we're taking a look at just a few AI do-gooders and what they're doing to fight climate change, make healthcare more accessible, and help their communities.
articles.author: Phoebe Sajor

articles.title: Welcome to¬†the Eternal September of open source.¬†Here‚Äôs¬†what we plan to do for maintainers.
articles.description: Open source is hitting an ‚ÄúEternal September.‚Äù As contribution friction drops, maintainers are adapting with new trust signals, triage approaches, and community-led solutions. The post Welcome to the Eternal September of open source. Here’s what we plan to do for maintainers. appeared first on
articles.content: Open collaboration runs on trust. For a long time, that trust was protected by a natural, if imperfect filter: friction. If you were on Usenet in 1993, you’ll remember that every September a flood of new university students would arrive online, unfamiliar with the norms, and the community would patiently onboard them. Then mainstream dial-up ISPs became popular and a continuous influx of new users came online. It became the September that never ended . Today, open source is experiencing it
articles.author: Ashley Wolf

articles.title: Prompt Injection Is the ‚ÄúSocial Engineering‚Äù of AI Apps
articles.description: When people think about AI security, they often jump straight to jailbreaks, model theft, or hallucinations. But the risk that keeps showing up in real systems is more familiar than that. It looks like social engineering. Prompt injection happens when an LLM-based app can be steered by instructions
articles.content: When people think about AI security, they often jump straight to jailbreaks, model theft, or hallucinations. But the risk that keeps showing up in real systems is more familiar than that. It looks like social engineering. Prompt injection happens when an LLM-based app can be steered by instructions hidden inside content it‚Äôs asked to read‚Äîan email, a web page, a PDF, a shared doc, a ticket, a calendar invite. If your app treats that content as ‚Äúinstructions‚Äù instead of ‚Äúdata,‚Äù it becomes surpris
articles.author: Scott McMahan

In my life, I‚Äôve worked snack food pop-ups in a grocery store, ran the cash register for random merch booths, and even hawked my own plasma at $35 per vial. So, when I saw RentAHuman, a new site where AI agents hire humans to perform physical work in the real world on behalf of the virtual bots, I was eager to see how these AI overlords would compare to my past experiences with the gig economy. You come up with a creative angle, put together a team of specialists, figure out how to beat the technological challenges, rehearse,
articles.content: Making a movie is a lot like pulling off a heist. That‚Äôs what Steven Soderbergh‚Äîdirector of the Ocean‚Äôs franchise, among other heist-y classics‚Äî said a few years ago . You come up with a creative angle, put together a team of specialists, figure out how to beat the technological challenges, rehearse, move with Swiss-watch precision, and‚Äîif you do it right‚Äîredistribute some wealth. That could describe either the plot or the making of Ocean‚Äôs Eleven . But conversely, pulling off a heist isn‚Äôt much

This impacted chat features across Copilot Chat, VS Code, JetBrains IDEs, and other dependent products. The incident was triggered by a configuration error introduced during a model update and was initially mitiga

Yet for anyone familiar with Bezos' privately owned space company, Blue Origin, the message was clear. articles.author: Eric Berger

articles.title: Join the Research: Can NDM-TCP Handle the "Wild" Cases?
articles.description: The NDM-TCP project has reached a critical milestone. Through extensive loopback testing with Linux Traffic Control (tc), we have proven that our Neural Differential Manifolds approach out-performs traditional algorithms like Reno and Cubic in controlled environments. However, lab results are only h
articles.content: The NDM-TCP project has reached a critical milestone. Through extensive loopback testing with Linux Traffic Control (tc), we have proven that our Neural Differential Manifolds approach out-performs traditional algorithms like Reno and Cubic in controlled environments. However, lab results are only half the story. The ultimate test for any congestion control algorithm is the "Wild Case"‚Äîthe unpredictable, non-linear chaos of the actual internet. üß™ Beyond Emulation: The Need for Real-World Stress
articles.author: Muhammed Shafin P

articles.content: In our previous analysis, we explored what makes a wine "good." Today, we address a more strategic question: How big is the market, and who owns the largest slice of the pie? articles.content: If you're looking to expand the storage on your Switch 2, the 512GB Samsung P9 microSD Express card is on sale right now for 33 percent off, marked down to $80 from $120.
